3.heading: MOTION IN COMIC BOOKS, STRIPS, ETC.
3.title: "The Image in Motion"
3.author: by Tappan W
3.appears_in: King. p. 11-18 in Crimmer's: The Harvard Journal of Pictorial Fiction (Winter 1975)
notes: SUMMARY: "The author traces the 20th century's fascination with movement, starting from Muybridge's photographic dissection of a man running and evolving through various artistic schools and media, cubism in painting, Hogarth in narrative art, Griffith in film. Comics especially are examined for their evolution from the key figure of Winsor McCay." 1. History and criticism of comics. 2. Motion in comic books, strips, etc. 3. Muybridge, Edward, 1830-1904. 4. Hogarth, Burne. 5. Griffith, D. W. (David Wark), 1875-1948. 6. McCay, Winsor. I. King, Tappan W. k. Movement. Call no.: PN6700.H3 1975

76.heading: MOTION PICTURES--HISTORY.
76.title: "Film and Comic Art : A Critique of the Purist View"
76.author: Armand Eisen
76.appears_in: p. 12-15 in The Harvard Journal of Pictorial Fiction (Spring 1974)
notes: SUMMARY: "Rudolph Arnheim declares in his landmark Film as Art, 'The indirectness of language ... makes words fade into meaningless noise when they are forced to compete on an equal footing with visual and auditory action.' This is representative of the purist stand that film with sound and comics with dialogue and prose are hybrid, uncontrolled forms of artistic expression. The author argues that the 'sound' dimension is vital to the functional object of emotional involvement and aesthetically sound as partner to visual storytelling." 1. History and criticism of comics. 2. Motion pictures
History. 3. Arnheim, Rudolf. I. Eisen, Armand. k. Sound. k. Hybrids. Call no.: PN6700.H3 1974

145.heading: Motives.
145.title: "Special Agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation". 5 p. True Comics, no. 39
145.author: [No author]
notes: (7th story; pages 26-30 of magazine; mentioned on cover)

SUMMARY: FBI Agent Steve Saunders goes to Arkansas, and his first case is bringing in a draft dodger, farmer Hurbie Rains. A battle with guns, shovels and axes ends with Hurbie wounded and the whole family in court. No motive for Hurbie's actions is given. 1. United States. Federal Bureau of Investigation. k. FBI agents. k. Arkansas. k. Draft dodgers. k. Farmers. k. Guns. k. Shovels. k. Axes. k. Family. k. Court. k. Motives. Call no.: PN6728.1.P3T7no.39
